Title: Machine Learning Operations for Accelerator Control
Authors: Tia Miceli (Lead - Accelerator AI/ML Group, Accelerator Controls Department, FNAL)

Table Descriptions.Description: Issues and mitigating best practices for model weight reproducibility in AI/ML
Issues and Mitigating Best Practices for AI/ML Reproducibility
Row Labels: Weights are so different that model predictions are very different.
Works for me, but not for you

Page Summaries: This page is a title slide for a presentation on Machine Learning Operations for Accelerator Control by Tia Miceli, a lead member of the Accelerator AI/ML Group in the Accelerator Controls Department at FNAL. The presentation is part of the EPICS Collaboration Meeting taking place from 24-28 April 2023.

This page highlights the importance of creating sustainable methods for developing, deploying, monitoring, and servicing machine learning applications in particle accelerators. It addresses challenges such as the loss of key personnel, reproducibility issues in deep learning, and lifecycle handling of the applications.

The slide emphasizes the importance of sustainable practices in developing, deploying, monitoring, and servicing machine learning applications for accelerators, focusing on challenges such as personnel turnover, reproducibility in deep learning, and lifecycle management.

The page discusses the reproducibility problem in AI/ML, specifically the difficulty in reproducing the same model weights across different training sessions. It includes a table that outlines issues and their mitigating best practices.

The page discusses common issues related to the reproducibility problem in AI and Machine Learning. It outlines a variety of issues that can arise, categorizes them into typical and tricky issues, and provides best practice mitigating strategies for each issue to ensure reproducibility in training AI/ML models.

The page discusses the challenges of deploying AI models in accelerator control, emphasizing the risks of data drift and model performance degradation. It suggests using MLOps for data and performance monitoring, alarming, triggering workflows, and automating model retraining and deployment.

This page covers the essentials of deploying machine learning operations (MLOps), emphasizing the necessity of comprehensive AI/ML capabilities for operations beyond mere data science tasks. It outlines the engineering and stewardship required to support activities such as live-streaming data ingestion, model inference serving, prediction streaming, logging, monitoring, and automating actions.

This page presents a diagram illustrating the workflow for machine learning operations (MLOps) in accelerator control. The workflow is divided into stages including Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, Operations Development, and System Operations, detailing the steps of collecting data, labeling/splitting data, and releasing data.

This page presents a diagram that outlines the workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) specifically within the context of accelerator control. It breaks down the process into four main stages: Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, Operations Development, and System Operations, detailing specific tasks within each stage, such as standardized data logging and dataset management.

This page illustrates the workflow for machine learning operations (MLOps) in accelerator control, outlining the process from data management and AI/ML modeling to operations development and system operations. It also highlights the importance of standardized data logging, interfaces for machine learning engineers, and dataset management systems.

This page presents a diagram outlining the workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps). The workflow includes stages such as Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, Operations Development, and System Operations. There are also notes on using standardized tools and systems for model development and dataset management.

This page presents a detailed workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps), highlighting the steps involved in Data Management and AI/ML Modeling. It lists standardized tools and systems used in model development and dataset management, with an emphasis on maintaining a standardized format and tracking data versions.

This page outlines the workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) used in accelerator control, detailing stages such as Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, and the use of common tools for model development. The aim is to standardize and streamline processes for efficiency and optimization in system operations.

This page provides a workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps), explaining the steps involved in Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, and Operations Development to enhance accelerator control. It also highlights the tools and standardized formats used to optimize the process.

This page presents a detailed diagram of the workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps), covering stages such as Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, and Operations Development. It highlights standardized tools and interfaces for ML Engineers and provides an overview of processes including data collection, model training, and deployment.

This page presents the Workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) consisting of several stages: Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, Operations Development, and System Operations. The workflow includes steps like collecting data, labeling, training models, entering models into a registry, and deploying models in system operations. Essential tools and practices are also highlighted, including the Data Management System, Model Development System, and the Model Registry.

This page discusses the workflow for machine learning operations (MLOps) in accelerator control. It details the various stages involved, including Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, Operations Development, and System Operations. The diagram provides a detailed view of the interactions and processes at each stage.

This page presents an overview of the workflow for implementing machine learning operations in accelerator control. It details the stages from data management and AI/ML modeling to operations development and system operations, highlighting standardized data formats, model development tools, and interfaces for ML engineers.

This page discusses the relationship between MLOps (Machine Learning Operations) and DevOps (Development Operations). It highlights the importance of integrating and streamlining software development and deployment using agile practices and CI/CD (Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery), along with emphasizing modern code version control, strict permissions on merging, and appropriate testing sizes. There's a fun fact noting DevOps' roots in Lean Manufacturing practices.

This page provides a diagram that describes the necessary infrastructure for implementing machine learning operations (MLOps) in accelerator controls. It covers aspects of data management, model development, operations development, and system operations, as well as common tools required for these processes.

The page discusses Fermilab's efforts to build and enhance their accelerator control systems using MLOps. It includes formalizations for system integration, collaborations with other laboratories, and the development of open source tools on a Kubernetes cluster.

This page discusses the Fermilab Accelerator Controls AI/ML Group's initiative to design a Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) infrastructure. The presenter, Tia Miceli, invites feedback on effective and ineffective workflow practices.

The page serves as a promotional flyer for the 4th ICFA Beam Dynamics Mini-Workshop focused on Machine Learning Applications for Particle Accelerators, taking place from 5 to 8 March 2024 in Gyeongju, Republic of Korea. The institutions involved include the Pohang Accelerator Laboratory and POSTECH.
